correct: Richard Sherman sent the Seahawks to their second-ever Super Bowl when he tipped 49ers QB Colin Kaepernick's pass, intended for Michael Crabtree, into the arms of Seattle linebacker Malcolm Smith. The play, arguably the most important in franchise history, sealed Seattle's 23-17 victory over San Francisco in the NFC Championship game Jan. 19, 2014, at CenturyLink Field.

After publicly proclaiming he would shut down the rookie running back, the Boz — Seattle's controversial rookie linebacker — got manhandled by Jackson, giving up a 91-yard touchdown and getting bulldozed at the goal line as Bo bested Boz and the Seahawks for a "MNF"-record 221 rushing yards on Nov. 30, 1987, at the Kingdome. Los Angeles won 37-14.

While rookie Steve Largent was the standout in Seattle's inaugural 1976 season, the first Seahawks touchdown ever recorded came on a 12-yard Jim Zorn pass to McCullum in the Kingdome end zone behind San Francisco cornerback Anthony Leonard.

It was a simple power run to the right, but Lynch took the rock and carried it off into Seahawks history. The 67-yard touchdown run famously caused fans at Qwest Field to cheer so hard they registered on a nearby seismometer, and the 7-9 Seahawks upset the defending Super Bowl-champion Saints, 41-36, on Jan, 8, 2011, to advance in the playoffs.

Fans mostly blame the questionable officiating for Seattle's loss in Super Bowl XL, but the Seahawks did plenty to lose that game Feb. 5, 2006, in Detroit. With a struggling offense, they asked Josh Brown to kick from 54 then 50 yards out during the heart of the game, but he couldn't convert either attempt, allowing the Steelers to pull away for the eventual 21-10 victory.

After upsetting the 12-4 Dolphins and reaching a conference championship game for the first time in franchise history, the 9-7 Seahawks fell to the Raiders, 30-14, in a mostly lopsided affair Jan. 8, 1984, at L.A.'s Memorial Coliseum. That season marked the true birth of a divisional rivalry with the Raiders and cemented "Ground Chuck" Knox as one of the grestest coaches in Seattle history.

Running back Shaun Alexander scored a record five touchdowns — four rushing, one receiving — in the first half of a 48-23 beatdown against the Vikings at what was then called Seahawks Stadium. Seattle scored four times in the final 1:47 before halftime Sept. 29, 2002.

Heading into Seattle's 43-8 win in Super Bowl XLVIII, few people would have guessed a backup linebacker would end up the game's hero. But Malcolm Smith's 69-yard pick-six just before halftime, his third-quarter fumble recovery and his nine combined tackles Feb. 2, 2014, earned him a trip to Disney World.

Now one of just three Seahawks in the Pro Football Hall of Fame, Cortez Kennedy was named a Pro Bowler in eight of his 11 NFL seasons. His final Pro Bowl appearance came in 1999, when the defensive tackle plucked two interceptions out of the air.

Pictured here with former Seahawks QB Jim Zorn during ceremonies honoring Steve Largent's last NFL game Dec. 23, 1989, the legendary receiver was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1995, becoming the first Seattle player enshrined in Canton, Ohio. Largent would be joined by Cortez Kennedy in 2012 and Walter Jones in 2014.

The Seahawks led the Jets 31-26 with 26 seconds left Dec. 3, 1998, when Jets QB Vinny Testaverde kept the ball and rushed 5 yards up the middle for a touchdown. Or was it? Video replays showed the ball never crossed the line, but the officials thought Testaverde's helmet was the ball and signaled a touchdown. The refs couldn't consult the tape, and Seattle lost that "Monday Night Football" game 32-31. The infamous call helped usher in the return of instant replay to the NFL.

Now widely known as the worst call in Super Bowl history, the pass was supposed to be a quick toss to Ricardo Lockette for either an easy touchdown or an incompletion, stopping the clock with a few seconds remaining. But as Seattle fans know all too well, Patriots cornerback Malcolm Butler anticipated the play, picking off Russell Wilson and sealing New England's 28-24 victory in Super Bowl XLIX on Feb. 1, 2015.

For NFL fans, the Seahawks' 14-12 "Fail Mary" win over the Packers in Week 3 of the 2012 season was the last straw — as it was for the league and the officials, too. Just two days later, the NFL agreed to new labor terms with its regular officials and said goodbye to the replacements who stood in early that season.

In his final game in a Seahawks uniform, QB Matt Hasselbeck nearly orchestrated a comeback for the ages against the Bears in the divisional playoffs Jan. 8, 2011, in snowy Chicago. Trailing 28-3 at the start of the fourth quarter, Hasselbeck tossed three touchdowns to cut the Bears' lead to 35-24. But it was too little, too late, and Chicago ended Seattle's unlikely, Beast Quake-fueled postseason run.

Though Ken Behring may be the Seahawks' best known previous owner, infamous for trying to move the team to Los Angeles, he was not part of the original ownership group in 1976. Pictured here are the original owners. Standing from left: Howard S. Wright, D.D. "Ned" Skinner and Herman Sarkowski. Sitting from left: M. Lamont Bean, Elmer Nordstom and Lynn P. Himmelman.
